column1: What is the main characteristic of 'dynamically linked libraries (DLLs)'?

column4: They contain only data and cannot include any executable code.
column5: They are exclusively used by operating system kernel modules.
column6: They must be manually compiled and linked by the user for every program.
column8: The glossary defines 'dynamically linked libraries (DLLs)' as: 'System libraries that are linked to user programs when the processes are run, with linking postponed until execution time.'

column1: Which of the following is a key advantage of using dynamically linked libraries (DLLs)?
column2: They force all programs to load all available libraries, regardless of need.
column3: They eliminate the need for a compiler, speeding up development.
column4: They prevent programs from accessing system resources.
column5: They avoid loading unused libraries and allow multiple processes to share common libraries, saving memory.
column6: They ensure that programs are completely isolated from each other's memory spaces.
column8: The text highlights the benefits: 'This avoids loading unused libraries and allows multiple processes to share common libraries, saving memory.'

column6: create_process() then start()

column6: Windows Executable (WINEX)

column3: Debugging
column4: Optimization

column1: What is the primary reason applications compiled on one operating system are generally not executable on others?

column8: The text states that applications are generally not executable on other OSes due to 'unique system calls and other barriers'.

column1: Which of the following is NOT one of the three main ways an application can be made available to run on multiple operating systems?
column2: Using interpreted languages.
column3: Embedding the entire operating system within the application.
column4: Utilizing virtual machines.
column5: Employing standard languages/APIs with subsequent porting.
column6: None of the above; all are listed methods.
column8: The text lists interpreted languages, virtual machines, and standard language/API with porting as the three ways. Embedding the entire OS is not mentioned.

column1: Applications written in interpreted languages like Python or Ruby achieve cross-platform compatibility by:
column2: Compiling directly into machine-specific binaries for each OS.
column3: Relying on a virtual machine to emulate the target OS.
column4: Using an interpreter available for multiple operating systems that executes equivalent native instructions.
column5: Requiring manual recoding of the application for each new platform.
column6: Automatically converting their code into C++ before execution.
column8: The text explains that interpreted languages 'use an interpreter available for multiple operating systems. The interpreter executes equivalent native instructions and calls native OS functions.'

column1: What are common disadvantages associated with using interpreted languages and virtual machines for cross-platform application compatibility?
column2: Increased security vulnerabilities and higher development costs.
column3: Reduced performance and potential limitations on features.
column4: Strict dependency on specific hardware architectures.
column5: Inability to interact with native operating system functions.
column6: Requirement for a separate license for each operating system.
column8: For both interpreted languages and virtual machines, the text notes that 'Performance may suffer, and features might be limited' or 'This approach has similar disadvantages to interpreters.'

column1: The 'standard language/API with porting' approach for cross-platform compatibility involves:
column2: Creating a single binary that runs universally on all operating systems.
column3: Using a language where the compiler generates machine- and OS-specific binaries, requiring the application to be ported to each OS.
column4: Translating the application code into a different language for each target platform.
column5: Leveraging a cloud-based service to stream the application to users.
column6: Designing the application to run exclusively in a web browser.
column8: The text describes this method as when 'Application developers use a standard language or API where the compiler generates machine- and OS-specific binaries. The application must be ported to each OS.'

column1: Which of the following is an architectural difference that makes cross-platform application development challenging?

column3: Differences in network protocols used by operating systems.
column4: Unique binary formats for applications across different OSes.
column5: The number of concurrent users supported by the OS.
column6: The preferred file system type (e.g., NTFS vs. EXT4).
column8: The text lists 'Binary formats: Each OS has a unique binary format' as a key architectural difference.

column1: What role do CPU instruction sets play in the challenge of cross-platform application development?
column2: They determine the maximum RAM an application can use.
column3: They vary across different CPUs, requiring applications to contain appropriate instructions for correct execution.
column4: They dictate the graphical user interface of an application.
column5: They define the network communication protocols.
column6: They are standardized globally and pose no challenge.

column1: Operating system system calls vary significantly in which aspects?

column6: The amount of CPU time they are allowed to consume.

column1: What is the ELF format primarily used for, as adopted by Linux?

column4: Specifying user interface guidelines.
column5: Managing file system permissions.
column6: Encrypting application data.
column8: The text mentions 'Linux's adoption of the ELF format for binary executable files provide a common standard across Linux and UNIX systems'.

column1: While the ELF format provides a common standard for binary executables across Linux and UNIX systems, what does it NOT guarantee?
column2: Compatibility with different file system types.
column3: Cross-hardware platform compatibility.
column4: Interoperability with Windows applications.
column5: Support for interpreted languages.
column6: Enhanced graphics rendering.
column8: The text explicitly states that ELF 'do not guarantee cross-hardware platform compatibility'.

column1: What does an Application Binary Interface (ABI) define?
column2: How applications manage graphical user interfaces across different OSes.
column3: The standards for network communication between applications.
column4: How different components of binary code interface for a given operating system on a specific architecture.
column5: The licensing agreements for commercial software.
column6: The programming language syntax for system-level development.
column8: The glossary defines ABI as 'Defines how different components of binary code can interface for a given operating system on a given architecture.' The main text also reiterates this definition.

column1: Which of the following is NOT typically specified by an Application Binary Interface (ABI)?
column2: Address width.
column3: Parameter passing methods for system calls.
column4: The color scheme of the operating system's desktop environment.
column5: Runtime stack organization.
column6: Data type sizes.
column8: The text lists address width, parameter passing methods for system calls, runtime stack organization, binary format of system libraries, and data type sizes as low-level details specified by ABIs. Desktop color scheme is not mentioned.

column1: What is the key limitation of an Application Binary Interface (ABI) regarding cross-platform compatibility?
column2: It only supports open-source software.
column3: It is defined for a specific OS and architecture, thus not providing cross-platform compatibility.
column4: It is only compatible with virtualized environments.
column5: It only ensures compatibility for applications written in assembly language.
column6: It increases the overall size of binary executables.
column8: The text clearly states, 'While an ABI ensures compatibility on systems supporting that ABI, it does not provide cross-platform compatibility as it is defined for a specific OS and architecture.'

column1: What does the term 'port' mean in the context of software development?
column2: To secure a network connection.
column3: To debug a software application.
column4: To move code from its current platform to another platform (e.g., between operating systems or hardware systems).
column5: To compress a large software file.
column6: To install a new operating system.
column8: The glossary defines 'port' as 'To move code from its current platform to another platform (e.g., between operating systems or hardware systems).'

column1: Based on the text, why does a program like Firefox require extensive work to run across various platforms (Windows, macOS, Linux, iOS, Android) and CPU architectures?

column4: To comply with different international software regulations.

column6: To ensure maximum compatibility with outdated hardware.
column8: The summary states, 'these differences necessitate that applications are written for and compiled on a specific operating system and CPU type (e.g., Intel x86 or ARM v8) unless an interpreter or RTE is used. This explains the extensive work required for programs like Firefox to run across various platforms.'

column1: Which of the following best defines 'debugging' in the context of operating system development?
column2: The process of installing new software updates.

column4: The activity of analyzing program performance to identify bottlenecks.
column5: The creation of new system features and functionalities.
column6: The process of backing up system data to prevent loss.
column8: Debugging is explicitly defined as 'the process of finding and fixing errors, or bugs' in the text.

column1: In operating system development, what is considered a 'bug'?
column2: A physical defect in hardware components.
column3: A type of network anomaly.
column4: An error in a program.
column5: A security vulnerability discovered in an application.
column6: A user-reported issue with system usability.
column8: The text's glossary defines 'bug' as 'An error in a program.'

column2: The limited availability of debugging tools.
column3: The difficulty of reproducing errors and the system's concurrent nature.
column4: The high cost of debugging software licenses.
column5: The lack of experienced debugging professionals.
column6: The inability to access system logs.
column8: The text states that debugging 'can be challenging due to the difficulty of reproducing errors and the system's concurrent nature.'

column1: What is the purpose of 'log files' as a debugging tool?
column2: To store backup copies of the operating system.
column3: To record the sequence of events or function calls during program execution.
column4: To provide a snapshot of a process's memory at the time of a crash.
column5: To analyze program performance and identify bottlenecks.
column6: To record system-generated events, errors, and warnings for analysis.
column8: Log files are described as 'System-generated files that record events, errors, and warnings. Analyzing these logs helps identify the cause of issues.'

column1: A 'core dump' is most accurately described as:
column2: A file containing the current state of all active processes on a system.
column3: A snapshot of the memory of a specific process at the time of a crash, useful for post-mortem analysis.
column4: A complete backup of the operating system's kernel and drivers.
column5: A detailed record of network traffic and communication errors.
column6: A list of all hardware components and their current status.
column8: A core dump is defined as 'A snapshot of the memory of a process at the time of a crash. It contains the state of the program, including register values, stack, and memory, useful for post-mortem analysis.' The glossary also states: 'A file containing the state of a program when it crashed.'

column1: How does a 'crash dump' (or 'system dump') differ from a 'core dump'?
column2: A crash dump captures the state of a specific application, while a core dump captures system performance metrics.
column3: A crash dump is exclusively used for hardware failures, whereas a core dump is for software bugs.
column4: A crash dump is a snapshot of the entire operating system's state when it crashes, while a core dump is for a single process.
column5: A crash dump is a real-time monitoring tool, and a core dump is a post-mortem analysis tool.
column6: There is no difference; the terms are interchangeable.
column8: The text states a crash dump is 'Similar to a core dump but for the entire operating system. It captures the system's state when a kernel panic or system crash occurs.' Conversely, a core dump is for a process.

column1: Which debugging tool allows developers to step through code, inspect variables, and set breakpoints to understand program execution flow?
column2: Log files
column3: Core dump
column4: Debugger
column5: System monitor
column6: Benchmarking tool
column8: A debugger is described as 'A software tool that allows developers to step through code, inspect variables, and set breakpoints to understand program execution flow and identify bugs.'

column1: What is the primary objective of 'tracing' as a debugging technique?
column2: To identify which parts of a program consume the most resources.

column4: To measure system performance under specific workloads.
column5: To create a memory snapshot of a crashed process.
column6: To track real-time system resource usage.
column8: Tracing is defined as 'A technique to record the sequence of events or function calls during program execution, providing insights into behavior.'

column1: What is 'profiling' primarily used for in the context of debugging and system analysis?
column2: To detect and correct hardware errors.
column3: To manage and allocate system memory.
column4: To analyze program performance to identify bottlenecks and areas for optimization.
column5: To secure the operating system against external threats.
column6: To create detailed documentation of system architecture.
column8: Profiling is defined as 'Analyzing program performance to identify bottlenecks and areas for optimization.'

column1: 'Performance tuning' is an activity focused on which of the following?
column2: Enhancing system security protocols.
column3: Improving system efficiency.
column4: Detecting and fixing software bugs.
column5: Developing new application features.
column6: Creating user interface designs.
column8: Performance tuning is described as 'a related activity focused on improving system efficiency.' The glossary also defines it as 'An activity that improves the performance of a system.'

column2: Log files
column3: System monitors
column4: Benchmarking tools
column5: Profilers
column6: Debuggers
column8: Profilers are listed as tools for performance tuning that 'Identify which parts of a program consume the most resources (CPU, memory).'

column1: What is the primary function of 'system monitors' in the context of performance tuning?
column2: To measure system performance under specific workloads.
column3: To track real-time system resource usage like CPU utilization and memory usage.
column4: To capture the state of the operating system when it crashes.
column5: To record sequences of events for post-mortem analysis.
column6: To allow developers to step through code and inspect variables.
column8: System monitors 'Track real-time system resource usage (CPU utilization, memory usage, disk I/O, network activity).'

column1: What is the main purpose of 'benchmarking tools'?
column2: To find and fix errors in program code.
column3: To identify memory leaks in an application.
column4: To measure system performance under specific workloads for comparison.
column5: To record system-generated warnings and errors.
column6: To provide a step-by-step execution view of a program.
column8: Benchmarking tools 'Measure system performance under specific workloads to compare against baselines or other systems.'

column1: What is the primary reason operating systems are structured into components or modules?
column2: To maximize hardware utilization only.
column3: To ensure they are solely open-source.
column4: For proper function and easy modification.
column5: To strictly limit their size to a few kilobytes.
column6: To avoid the need for any form of memory management.
column8: Operating systems are structured into components or modules for proper function and easy modification, allowing for better organization and maintainability.

column1: Which operating system structure places all kernel functionality in a single, static binary file within one address space?
column2: Microkernel structure
column3: Layered approach
column4: Modular design
column5: Monolithic structure
column6: Hybrid system
column8: The monolithic structure is defined by having all kernel functionality contained within a single, static binary file in one address space.

column1: Which of the following is an example of an operating system that originally utilized a monolithic kernel?
column2: Mach
column3: Original UNIX OS
column4: QNX
column5: macOS
column6: Android
column8: The original UNIX OS is cited as an example of a system that employed a monolithic kernel structure.

column1: While Linux uses a monolithic kernel, what design characteristic allows for runtime modification?
column2: Its pure microkernel design.
column3: Its strict layered approach.
column4: Its modular design.
column5: Its exclusive use of user-level programs.
column6: Its reliance on external hardware for all modifications.
column8: Linux, despite having a monolithic kernel, incorporates a modular design that enables runtime modification, often through loadable kernel modules (LKMs).

column1: What is a primary advantage of the monolithic operating system structure?
column2: Ease of extension and modification.
column3: Minimal performance overhead due to fast internal communication.
column4: Simplicity in construction and debugging.
column5: Enhanced security by isolating components.
column6: Automatic portability across different hardware architectures.
column8: A significant advantage of monolithic kernels is high performance, attributed to minimal overhead and fast internal communication within a single address space.

column1: A key disadvantage of the monolithic operating system structure is that it is:
column2: Inefficient in communication.
column3: Too loosely coupled for proper function.
column4: Difficult to implement and extend.
column5: Prone to excessive message passing.
column6: Limited to only one type of hardware.
column8: Monolithic kernels are known for being difficult to implement and extend due to their single, large, and interconnected codebase.

column1: In the context of operating systems, what does 'tightly coupled systems' refer to?
column2: Processors that share no resources.
column3: Systems with separate memory spaces for all components.
column4: Processors in close communication, sharing resources.
column5: Operating systems that are difficult to debug.
column6: Kernel components that are entirely independent.
column8: 'Tightly coupled systems' specifically refers to processors in close communication, sharing resources, often seen in monolithic kernel designs.

column1: Which term best describes a kernel composed of components with specific, limited functions, as found in a layered approach?
column2: Tightly coupled
column3: Monolithic
column4: Loosely coupled
column5: Static binary
column6: Microkernel
column8: 'Loosely coupled' describes a system or kernel composed of components with specific, limited functions, characteristic of the layered approach.

column1: In the layered approach to operating system structure, how do layers interact?
column2: Any layer can directly call functions from any other layer.
column3: Each layer uses functions only from higher layers.
column4: Layers communicate exclusively via message passing.
column5: Each layer uses functions only from lower layers.
column6: Layers interact only through recompilation.
column8: A fundamental concept of the layered approach is that each layer uses functions exclusively from layers below it, starting from Layer 0 (hardware) up to Layer N (user interface).

column1: What is a major advantage of the layered approach in operating system design?
column2: Superior performance due to minimal layer traversals.
column3: Automatic definition of layers for any system.
column4: Simplicity in construction and debugging.
column5: Complete isolation of all kernel components.
column6: Ability to dynamically load new services without recompilation.
column8: The layered approach's primary advantage is its simplicity in construction and debugging, as issues can often be isolated to specific layers.

column1: What is a significant disadvantage of a pure layered operating system structure?
column2: It simplifies debugging too much, leading to complacency.
column3: It always leads to high performance.
column4: Challenges in defining layers and potential poor performance due to multiple layer traversals.
column5: It prevents the use of any user interface.
column6: It requires all kernel functionality in a single address space.
column8: Disadvantages of the layered approach include difficulties in defining appropriate layers and potential poor performance due to the overhead of multiple layer traversals for a single request.

column1: What defines a microkernel operating system structure?
column2: All kernel functionality is in a single, static binary file.
column3: The kernel is divided into strictly separate, functional layers.
column4: Nonessential components are removed from the kernel and implemented as user-level programs in separate address spaces.
column5: Dynamic linking of additional services into the core kernel.
column6: It is a combination of monolithic and layered approaches.
column8: A microkernel removes nonessential components from the kernel, implementing them as user-level programs in separate address spaces, resulting in a smaller kernel.

column1: Which of the following is considered a core function of a microkernel?
column2: Web browser hosting.
column3: Extensive device driver management.
column4: Minimal process/memory management and communication facility.
column5: User interface design.
column6: Complex file system operations.
column8: Microkernels are designed to include only essential functions, typically minimal process management, memory management, and a communication facility for inter-process communication.

column1: How do components primarily communicate in a microkernel architecture?
column2: Direct shared memory access.
column3: Through system call traps directly to hardware.
column4: Indirectly via message passing through the microkernel.
column5: By directly invoking functions in other components' address spaces.
column6: Through hardware-level interrupts only.
column8: Communication in microkernel systems is indirect, primarily occurring through message passing facilitated by the microkernel itself.

column1: Which of these is NOT a stated benefit of microkernels?
column2: Easier OS extension and modification.
column3: Enhanced security and reliability.
column4: Easier portability.
column5: Significantly higher performance due to direct memory access.
column6: Reduced kernel size.
column8: While microkernels offer benefits like easier extension, portability, security, and reliability, their performance can suffer due to overheads like message copying and process switching, making 'significantly higher performance' an incorrect benefit.

column1: Which of the following is an example of an operating system that utilizes a microkernel?
column2: Original UNIX OS
column3: Linux
column4: Mach
column5: Windows 10
column6: Android
column8: Mach is specifically cited as a microkernel OS, which forms the kernel of Darwin (macOS/iOS).

column1: What is the primary function of Loadable Kernel Modules (LKMs)?
column2: To remove essential components from the kernel.
column3: To define strict layers of OS functionality.
column4: To allow dynamic linking of additional services to the kernel.
column5: To force kernel recompilation for every change.
column6: To convert user-level programs into kernel components.
column8: LKMs enable the dynamic linking of additional services into the kernel, avoiding the need for a full kernel recompilation when changes or additions are made.

column1: How does the modular design of operating systems, utilizing LKMs, avoid the need for kernel recompilation for every change?
column2: By strictly adhering to a layered approach.
column3: By making all services static within the kernel.
column4: By providing core services in the kernel and allowing others to be dynamic.
column5: By implementing all functionality as user-level programs.
column6: By using only tightly coupled components.
column8: The modular design allows the kernel to provide core services while additional services can be dynamically loaded as modules, thus avoiding recompilation for many changes.

column1: How do operating system modules generally compare to a pure layered approach and microkernels in terms of flexibility and efficiency?
column2: Less flexible than layered, less efficient than microkernels.
column3: More flexible than layered, less efficient than microkernels.
column4: Less flexible than layered, more efficient than microkernels.
column5: More flexible than layered, more efficient than microkernels.
column6: Equally flexible and efficient as both.
column8: Modules are described as being more flexible than layered systems and more efficient than microkernels, striking a balance between the two.

column1: What specific components does Linux commonly use Loadable Kernel Modules (LKMs) for?
column2: User interface elements and application frameworks.
column3: Core process and memory management.
column4: Device drivers and file systems.
column5: Network protocols and communication facilities.
column6: Hardware abstraction layers and C libraries.
column8: Linux extensively uses LKMs for dynamic insertion and removal of components like device drivers and file systems.

column1: What is the primary characteristic of hybrid operating systems?
column2: They exclusively use a microkernel design.
column3: They strictly adhere to a monolithic structure.
column4: They combine different kernel structures to balance various goals.
column5: They are only used in mobile devices.
column6: They never allow user-level programs to access kernel services.
column8: Hybrid systems are designed to combine different kernel structures to achieve a balance of performance, security, and usability.

column1: Which of the following best describes the hybrid structure of the Linux kernel?
column2: Pure microkernel.
column3: Strictly layered.
column4: Monolithic with modular design.
column5: Pure monolithic, no modularity.
column6: Microkernel with no core services.
column8: Linux is described as having a hybrid structure that combines a monolithic kernel with modular design, allowing for dynamic modifications.

column1: Windows is characterized as a hybrid operating system, largely monolithic. What other architectural behaviors does it incorporate?
column2: Pure layered structure with no dynamic modules.
column3: Exclusively microkernel design for all functionalities.
column4: Microkernel-like behavior with user-mode subsystems and dynamically loadable kernel modules.
column5: Only strictly defined application frameworks.
column6: Reliance solely on an open-source kernel.
column8: Windows is a hybrid system, largely monolithic, but also incorporates microkernel-like behavior via user-mode subsystems and utilizes dynamically loadable kernel modules.

column1: What kind of overall structure do Apple's macOS and iOS operating systems share?
column2: Strictly monolithic.
column3: Pure microkernel.
column4: Layered structure.
column5: Modular only.
column6: Flat, unstructured kernel.

column2: Application frameworks layer
column3: Core frameworks
column4: Kernel environment

column1: Which two circumstances allow for a scheduling choice to be made by the operating system?

column8: CPU-scheduling decisions occur under four circumstances. For circumstances where a process switches from running to ready (e.g., interrupt occurs) or from waiting to ready (e.g., I/O completion), choices exist for scheduling a new process. No choice is made when a process switches from running to waiting or terminates, as a new process *must* be selected.

column1: What is a significant characteristic of preemptive CPU scheduling?

column1: How do nonpreemptive kernels handle context switching compared to preemptive kernels?

column3: It increases the average waiting time for processes.
column4: It results in many context switches, increasing overhead.
column5: It makes the algorithm nonpreemptive.
column6: It causes indefinite blocking or starvation.
column8: A small quantum results in many context switches, increasing overhead, as the system spends more time switching than executing processes.

column1: What is the recommended relationship between the time quantum and context-switch time for efficient Round-Robin scheduling?
column2: Context-switch time should be much larger than the time quantum.
column3: They should be exactly equal for optimal performance.
column4: Context-switch time should be large relative to the time quantum (e.g., > 50%).
column5: Time quantum should be large relative to context-switch time (e.g., context-switch time < 10% of time quantum).
column6: There is no significant relationship between them.
column8: Time quantum should be large relative to context-switch time (e.g., context-switch time < 10% of time quantum) to minimize overhead.

column1: What rule of thumb is suggested for the length of CPU bursts relative to the time quantum in Round-Robin scheduling?
column2: All CPU bursts must be exactly equal to the time quantum.
column3: No CPU burst should exceed the time quantum.
column4: 80% of CPU bursts should be shorter than the time quantum.
column5: All CPU bursts should be longer than the time quantum.
column6: The sum of all CPU bursts should equal the total time quantum.
column8: A rule of thumb is that 80% of CPU bursts should be shorter than the time quantum, which allows most processes to finish without being preempted unnecessarily.

column1: The Shortest-Job-First (SJF) algorithm is considered a special case of which general scheduling algorithm?
column2: First-Come, First-Served (FCFS)
column3: Round-Robin (RR)
column4: Priority-scheduling
column5: Multilevel Queue Scheduling
column6: Multilevel Feedback Queue Scheduling
column8: The SJF algorithm is a special case of the general priority-scheduling algorithm.

column1: In priority scheduling, how are processes with equal priority typically handled?
column2: They are scheduled randomly.
column3: They are scheduled in Last-In, First-Out (LIFO) order.
column4: They are scheduled using a Round-Robin approach.
column5: They are scheduled in First-Come, First-Served (FCFS) order.
column6: They are sent to a lower-priority queue.
column8: Equal-priority processes are scheduled in FCFS order.

column1: What defines the priority in SJF when viewed as a priority-scheduling algorithm?
column2: It's based on arrival time, with earlier arrival meaning higher priority.
column3: Priority is the inverse of the predicted next CPU burst (shorter burst = higher priority).
column4: It's determined by the memory requirements of the process (less memory = higher priority).
column5: Priority is assigned externally by the system administrator.
column6: It depends on the number of I/O operations a process performs.
column8: SJF is a priority algorithm where priority is the inverse of the (predicted) next CPU burst (shorter burst = higher priority).

column1: What is the major problem associated with priority scheduling?
column2: Excessive context switching.
column3: Difficulty in estimating CPU burst times.
column4: Indefinite blocking or starvation of low-priority processes.
column5: Degeneration to FCFS for large quantum sizes.
column6: Inefficient use of I/O devices.
column8: The major problem with priority scheduling is indefinite blocking or starvation, where low-priority processes may wait indefinitely for the CPU.

column1: Which technique is used to prevent starvation in priority-scheduling algorithms?
column2: Time slicing.
column3: Context switching.
column4: Aging.
column5: Dynamic priority reassignment.
column6: Shortest-Job-First (SJF).
column8: A solution to starvation is aging, which gradually increases the priority of processes that wait for a long time.

column1: What defines a 'multilevel queue' scheduling algorithm?
column2: It allows processes to move between different queues based on their behavior.
column3: It partitions the ready queue into several separate queues, each potentially with its own scheduling algorithm.
column4: It assigns a single queue for all processes but uses multiple priority levels.
column5: It uses a single FIFO queue for all processes.
column6: It schedules processes only based on their memory footprint.
column8: Multilevel queue scheduling partitions the ready queue into several separate queues, and each queue may have its own scheduling algorithm.

column1: In a multilevel queue scheduling system, how are processes typically assigned to a queue?
column2: They move between queues based on their CPU burst behavior.
column3: They are dynamically assigned based on system load.
column4: They are typically permanently assigned to a queue.
column5: They are randomly assigned to any available queue.
column6: Their assignment changes based on aging.
column8: In multilevel queue scheduling, processes are typically permanently assigned to a queue.

column1: How does the multilevel feedback queue scheduling algorithm differ fundamentally from the multilevel queue algorithm?
column2: It uses only a single queue.
column3: It does not use fixed priorities among queues.
column4: It allows a process to move between queues.
column5: It only supports nonpreemptive scheduling.
column6: It primarily focuses on batch processes.
column8: The multilevel feedback queue scheduling algorithm allows a process to move between queues, unlike multilevel queue scheduling where processes are usually permanently assigned.

column1: What is the purpose of allowing processes to move between queues in a multilevel feedback queue scheduling algorithm?
column2: To ensure all processes receive equal CPU time regardless of burst characteristics.
column3: To keep I/O-bound and interactive processes (short CPU bursts) in higher-priority queues.
column4: To force all processes into the lowest-priority queue after some time.
column5: To increase the average waiting time for CPU-bound processes.
column6: To simplify the scheduling logic by reducing the number of queues.
column8: The multilevel feedback queue separates processes by CPU burst characteristics: processes using too much CPU time are moved to lower-priority queues, which keeps I/O-bound and interactive processes (short CPU bursts) in higher-priority queues.

column1: How is aging typically implemented within a multilevel feedback queue scheduling algorithm?
column2: By decreasing the time quantum for processes that wait too long.
column3: By permanently assigning waiting processes to the lowest priority queue.
column4: By moving processes that wait too long in lower-priority queues to higher-priority queues.
column5: By terminating processes that have been waiting for an extended period.
column6: By giving a bonus time quantum to processes that complete quickly.
column8: Aging is implemented by moving processes that wait too long in lower-priority queues to higher-priority queues, preventing starvation.

column1: Which scheduling algorithm is described as the 'most general and configurable CPU-scheduling algorithm' but also the 'most complex to define optimally'?
column2: First-Come, First-Served (FCFS)
column3: Shortest-Job-First (SJF)
column4: Round-Robin (RR)
column5: Multilevel Feedback Queue Scheduling
column6: Priority Scheduling
column8: The multilevel feedback queue is described as the most general and configurable CPU-scheduling algorithm, but also the most complex to define optimally.

column1: According to the glossary, what is 'starvation' in the context of CPU scheduling?
column2: A situation where a CPU-bound process monopolizes the CPU.
column3: A scheduling risk in which a thread that is ready to run never gets put onto the CPU due to the scheduling algorithm.
column4: The condition where a process requests I/O too frequently.
column5: When a system runs out of available memory for new processes.
column6: A temporary pause in process execution due to an interrupt.
column8: Starvation (or infinite blocking) is a scheduling risk in which a thread that is ready to run never gets put onto the CPU due to the scheduling algorithm - it is starved for CPU time.

column1: What is the main characteristic of a 'foreground' thread as defined in the glossary?
column2: It is a batch job with no interactive input.
column3: It runs with the lowest possible priority.
column4: It is interactive and has input directed to it.
column5: It primarily performs I/O operations.
column6: It is permanently assigned to a background queue.
column8: A foreground thread is interactive and has input directed to it (such as a window currently selected as active or a terminal window that is currently selected to receive input).

column1: What entity do modern operating systems primarily schedule for CPU execution?
column2: Processes
column3: User-level threads
column4: Kernel-level threads
column5: Lightweight processes
column6: Applications
column8: Modern operating systems schedule kernel-level threads, not processes.

column1: How do user-level threads gain access to a CPU for execution?
column2: They directly access the CPU.
column3: They are managed and scheduled by the operating system kernel directly.
column4: They are mapped to kernel-level threads, possibly via a Lightweight Process (LWP).
column5: They run independently of kernel-level threads.
column6: They must first be converted into full processes.
column8: User-level threads are managed by a thread library and must be mapped to kernel-level threads (possibly via a lightweight process, LWP) to run on a CPU.

column1: In the context of thread scheduling, what defines Process-Contention Scope (PCS)?
column2: The kernel schedules kernel-level threads among all threads in the system.
column3: The thread library schedules user-level threads onto available LWPs, with competition among threads within the same process.
column4: Competition for the CPU occurs among all processes in the system.
column5: Threads are scheduled directly onto the CPU without intermediate mapping.
column6: Only a single thread from a process can run at a time.
column8: Process-contention scope (PCS) is where the thread library schedules user-level threads onto available LWPs, and competition for the CPU occurs among threads within the same process.

column1: What characterizes System-Contention Scope (SCS) in thread scheduling?
column2: User-level threads compete for CPU time within a single process.
column3: The thread library manages scheduling exclusively.
column4: The kernel schedules kernel-level threads onto a CPU, with competition among all threads in the system.
column5: Scheduling is limited to threads of the same priority level.
column6: It applies only to many-to-one threading models.
column8: System-contention scope (SCS) is a method in which kernel schedules kernel-level threads onto a CPU, and competition for the CPU occurs among all threads in the system.

column1: Which of the following is typically true regarding Process-Contention Scope (PCS) scheduling?
column2: It guarantees time slicing among equal-priority threads.
column3: It is solely managed by the operating system kernel.
column4: It uses priority-based scheduling and preempts lower-priority threads.
column5: Competition for the CPU occurs among all threads in the system.
column6: It is the only scheduling scope used in one-to-one systems like Windows.
column8: PCS typically uses priority-based scheduling, preempting lower-priority threads.

column1: Under Process-Contention Scope (PCS), what is the guarantee regarding time slicing among equal-priority threads?
column2: Time slicing is always guaranteed.
column3: Time slicing is guaranteed only if there are enough LWPs.
column4: There is no guarantee of time slicing.
column5: Time slicing is managed by the kernel.
column6: Time slicing only occurs for higher-priority threads.
column8: The text states that for PCS, there is 'No guarantee of time slicing among equal-priority threads'.

column1: Which type of threading model system commonly schedules threads using *only* System-Contention Scope (SCS)?
column2: Many-to-many models
column3: Many-to-one models
column4: One-to-one models
column5: User-level only models
column6: Hybrid models
column8: Systems using the one-to-one model (e.g., Windows, Linux) schedule threads using only SCS.

column4: PTHREAD_SCOPE_LIBRARY

column6: PTHREAD_SCOPE_GLOBAL

column6: It disables time slicing for equal-priority threads.
column8: On many-to-many systems, PTHREAD_SCOPE_PROCESS schedules user-level threads onto LWPs managed by the thread library.

column1: When PTHREAD_SCOPE_SYSTEM is used on a many-to-many threading system, what is the resulting behavior?
column2: User-level threads are scheduled by the thread library onto available LWPs.
column3: It effectively uses a one-to-one policy by creating and binding an LWP for each user-level thread.
column4: Threads compete for the CPU only within their own process.
column5: The system switches to a many-to-one model.
column6: User-level threads are not mapped to kernel-level threads.
column8: PTHREAD_SCOPE_SYSTEM on many-to-many systems creates and binds an LWP for each user-level thread, effectively using a one-to-one policy.

column5: pthread_config_scope() and pthread_query_scope()
column6: set_thread_scope() and get_thread_scope()
column8: The functions for setting/getting contention scope are pthread_attr_setscope() and pthread_attr_getscope().

column1: Which operating systems are mentioned as only allowing PTHREAD_SCOPE_SYSTEM for thread scheduling?
column2: Windows and Solaris

column1: Which concept is introduced in systems with multiple processing cores to distribute workload?

column4: Load sharing
column5: Paging

column1: The term 'multiprocessor' commonly applies to which of the following architectures?

column1: In asymmetric multiprocessing, what is the role of the single main server processor?

column6: It manages private per-processor ready queues.

column1: Which of the following is a potential drawback of asymmetric multiprocessing?
column2: Increased data sharing complexity
column3: The main server can become a performance bottleneck.
column4: Poor utilization of other processors
column5: Lack of support in modern operating systems

column1: Which characteristic best defines symmetric multiprocessing (SMP)?
column2: A single processor manages all system resources.
column3: Each processor is self-scheduling.
column4: Processors are dedicated to specific tasks (e.g., I/O, user code).
column5: It only supports a common ready queue.
column6: It is primarily used in embedded systems.
column8: Symmetric multiprocessing (SMP) is defined by each processor being self-scheduling, meaning they examine a ready queue and select a thread to run.

column1: What is a potential issue with using a common ready queue in Symmetric Multiprocessing (SMP) systems?
column2: Reduced processor affinity
column3: It eliminates the need for locking mechanisms.
column4: It can lead to race conditions requiring locking, which may be a performance bottleneck.
column5: It is only suitable for heterogeneous multiprocessing.
column6: Processors become idle more frequently.
column8: When all threads are in a common ready queue in SMP, potential race conditions require locking, which can become a performance bottleneck.

column1: Which strategy for organizing threads in SMP systems typically avoids locking overhead and benefits from processor affinity?
column2: A single, global dispatcher queue
column3: Common ready queue
column4: Private per-processor queues
column5: Distributed hash table queues
column6: FIFO queues for all processes

column1: What is the primary benefit of contemporary hardware using multicore processor chips compared to systems with separate physical CPU chips?
column2: They support only coarse-grained multithreading.
column3: They are slower but consume more power.
column4: They are faster and consume less power.
column5: They eliminate the need for an operating system.
column6: They require only one level of scheduling.
column8: Multicore processors are faster and consume less power than systems with separate physical CPU chips, as stated in the text.

column1: What is a 'memory stall' in the context of processor operation?
column2: When a processor is idled by an operating system scheduler.
column3: When a processor waits for data from memory (e.g., due to cache miss), wasting significant time.
column4: When a processor runs out of tasks to execute.
column5: When a processor is unable to switch between hardware threads.
column6: When a processor attempts to access protected memory.
column8: A memory stall occurs when a processor waits for data from memory (e.g., due to cache miss), wasting significant time.

column1: How do many processor designs mitigate the issue of memory stalls?
column2: By increasing cache size only.
column3: By implementing single-threaded processing cores.
column4: By implementing multithreaded processing cores with two or more hardware threads per core.
column5: By reducing the number of cores on the chip.
column6: By using only coarse-grained multithreading.
column8: To mitigate memory stalls, many designs implement multithreaded processing cores with two or more hardware threads per core, allowing the core to switch threads if one stalls.

column1: Which term is synonymous with 'chip multithreading' (CMT)?
column2: Asymmetric multiprocessing
column3: Soft affinity
column4: Hyper-threading or Simultaneous Multithreading (SMT)
column5: Push migration
column6: NUMA scheduling
column8: Chip multithreading (CMT) is also known as hyper-threading or simultaneous multithreading (SMT).

column1: What distinguishes coarse-grained multithreading from fine-grained multithreading?
column2: Coarse-grained switches threads at instruction cycle boundaries, while fine-grained switches on long-latency events.
column3: Coarse-grained has low switching cost due to architectural design, while fine-grained has high switching cost due to pipeline flushing.
column4: Coarse-grained switches threads on long-latency events (e.g., memory stall) with high switching cost due to pipeline flushing, while fine-grained switches at a finer granularity (e.g., instruction cycle boundary) with low switching cost.
column5: Coarse-grained is for single-core processors, while fine-grained is for multicore processors.
column6: Coarse-grained is a software-only approach, while fine-grained is hardware-based.
column8: Coarse-grained multithreading switches threads on long-latency events (e.g., memory stall) with high switching cost due to pipeline flushing. Fine-grained multithreading switches threads at a finer granularity (e.g., instruction cycle boundary) with low switching cost due to architectural design.

column1: In multithreaded, multicore processors, what are the two levels of scheduling required?
column2: Process scheduling and thread preemption.
column3: Operating system scheduling software threads onto hardware threads, and each core deciding which hardware thread to run.
column4: User-level scheduling and kernel-level scheduling.
column5: I/O scheduling and CPU scheduling.
column6: Batch scheduling and interactive scheduling.
column8: Multithreaded, multicore processors require two levels of scheduling: the operating system schedules software threads onto hardware threads (logical CPUs), and each core decides which hardware thread to run.

column1: What is the primary goal of load balancing in an SMP system?
column2: To ensure all processors are idle as much as possible.
column3: To keep the workload evenly distributed across all processors.
column4: To force all threads to run on a single processor.
column5: To eliminate the need for processor affinity.
column6: To centralize all scheduling decisions on one core.
column8: Load balancing attempts to keep the workload evenly distributed across all processors in an SMP system.

column1: Load balancing is generally necessary for SMP systems with which type of ready queue organization?
column2: Common ready queues
column3: Private per-processor ready queues
column4: Only systems using asymmetric multiprocessing
column5: Systems with no hardware threads
column6: Systems with only one level of scheduling
column8: Load balancing is necessary for systems with private per-processor ready queues because otherwise some processors might become idle while others are overloaded. It is unnecessary for common ready queues as the load is naturally balanced by processors pulling from the shared queue.

column1: In load balancing, what is 'push migration'?
column2: An idle processor requesting a task from a busy processor.
column3: A task periodically checks processor loads and moves threads from overloaded to idle/less-busy processors.
column4: A process being forced to switch contexts due to a higher priority task.
column5: The operating system automatically assigning new processes to the least busy core.
column6: A processor initiating a memory stall mitigation technique.
column8: With push migration, a specific task periodically checks the load on each processor andif it finds an imbalanceevenly distributes the load by moving (or pushing) threads from overloaded to idle or less-busy processors.

column1: What is 'pull migration' in the context of load balancing?
column2: An overloaded processor sending threads to another processor.
column3: A central scheduler reassigning threads to balance load.
column4: An idle processor pulling a waiting task from a busy processor.
column5: Threads autonomously migrating to different processors.
column6: A process requesting to be moved to a specific processor.
column8: Pull migration occurs when an idle processor pulls a waiting thread from a busy processor.

column1: What is 'processor affinity'?
column2: The ability of a processor to run multiple threads simultaneously.
column3: A process's preference to run on the processor where it is currently running or recently ran.
column4: The feature that allows multiple processors to share a common ready queue.
column5: A mechanism to balance load across all available processors.
column6: The process of disabling a processor to save power.
column8: Processor affinity means a process has an affinity for the processor on which it is currently running, largely due to the 'warm cache' benefit.

column1: What is the primary benefit of processor affinity for a process?
column2: It guarantees the process will always run on the same processor.
column3: It allows the process to utilize more CPU cores concurrently.
column4: It benefits from a 'warm cache', where recently accessed data is already in the processor's cache.
column5: It reduces the need for context switching.
column6: It simplifies the operating system's scheduling algorithm.
column8: Processor affinity benefits from 'warm cache', meaning data recently accessed by the thread populates the processor's cache, leading to faster access times.

column1: Which type of processor affinity allows the OS to attempt to keep a process on the same processor but does not guarantee it, allowing for migration during load balancing?
column2: Hard affinity
column3: Absolute affinity
column4: Soft affinity
column5: Fixed affinity
column6: Zero affinity
column8: Soft affinity is when the OS attempts to keep a process on the same processor but does not guarantee it, allowing migration during load balancing.

column1: What is 'hard affinity'?
column2: The default affinity setting for all processes.
column3: When a process has an affinity for any available processor.
column4: When system calls allow a process to specify a subset of processors on which it can run.
column5: An affinity that is easily changed by the operating system.
column6: An affinity that prevents any form of load balancing.
column8: Hard affinity is when system calls allow a process to specify a subset of processors on which it can run, effectively restricting its execution to those processors.

column1: In modern multicore NUMA systems, what is the tension between load balancing and minimizing memory access times?
column2: Load balancing typically enhances processor affinity, while minimizing memory access times requires migration.
column3: Load balancing often counteracts processor affinity benefits (which optimize memory access), as migrating a thread can incur cache invalidation costs.
column4: Load balancing only applies to systems without NUMA, thus no tension exists.
column5: Minimizing memory access times is solely a hardware concern, unrelated to load balancing.
column6: Both load balancing and memory access optimization are achieved by keeping threads on their initial processor.
column8: Load balancing often counteracts processor affinity benefits because migrating a thread to another processor incurs the cost of invalidating and repopulating caches, which increases memory access times, creating a tension with the goal of minimizing memory access times.

column1: What defines heterogeneous multiprocessing (HMP)?

column3: Systems with cores that vary in clock speed and power management but run the same instruction set.
column4: Systems where only one main processor handles all system tasks.
column5: Systems designed exclusively for cloud computing.
column6: Systems with only a single, high-performance core.
column8: Heterogeneous multiprocessing (HMP) refers to systems with cores that run the same instruction set but vary in clock speed and power management.

column5: HMP supports only 'big' cores, while asymmetric multiprocessing supports 'LITTLE' cores.
column6: HMP is an older concept, while asymmetric multiprocessing is newer.

column1: What is the primary intention behind heterogeneous multiprocessing (HMP) designs like ARM's big.LITTLE architecture?

column1: In ARM's big.LITTLE architecture, what is the typical role of the 'LITTLE' cores?
column2: Handling short, high-performance tasks with higher energy consumption.
column3: Managing I/O operations exclusively.
column4: Executing longer background tasks with lower energy consumption.

column1: Which of the following best describes a 'soft real-time system'?
column2: It guarantees that a critical real-time process will be serviced by its deadline, or it's considered a failure.
column3: It provides a strict guarantee on when a critical real-time process will be scheduled.

column6: It uses a first-come, first-served policy for all processes, irrespective of priority.

column1: What is the defining characteristic of a 'hard real-time system'?

column3: It allows critical processes to miss their deadlines occasionally without system failure.
column4: It has stricter requirements, where a task must be serviced by its deadline, or it is considered a failure.
column5: It guarantees that all processes will receive an equal share of CPU time.
column6: It relies solely on a round-robin scheduling policy for all tasks.
column8: Hard real-time systems have stricter requirements; a task must be serviced by its deadline, or it's considered a failure.

column1: What does 'event latency' refer to in real-time systems?

column3: The time elapsed from when an event occurs to when it is serviced.
column4: The delay between a user input and system response in non-real-time systems.
column5: The time it takes for a CPU to switch between two different processes.
column6: The period during which interrupts are disabled.
column8: Event latency is defined as the time elapsed from when an event occurs to when it is serviced.

column1: Which type of latency measures the time from an interrupt arrival at the CPU to the start of the interrupt service routine (ISR)?
column2: Dispatch latency
column3: Event latency
column4: Scheduling latency
column5: Interrupt latency
column6: Processing latency

column1: For hard real-time systems, how must interrupt latency be managed?

column1: What is 'dispatch latency'?

As the number of processes ($N$) approaches infinity, what percentage does the worst-case CPU utilization under Rate-Monotonic scheduling approach?
